text: Ragnar emerges from his house carrying the baby, wrapped blanket. The storm has passed. The wood and turf building one of several in the small hamlet perched on the edge of deep fjord. It’s a vision of stillness and utter tranquillity. The thickly wooded slopes of the fyord drop down sheer to the water, and above them the bare rocks ar still capped with snow. The whole landscape has a strange magical luminosity - a heightened, almost unnatural beaut Ragnar takes his son to the water’s edge and holds him ou his arms, like an offering.
Look Odin. Look, I have a son. Thank you, lord. Thank you for my son. We move in CLOSE on the baby’s face - then the camera til up towards the sky. And suddenly the sky begins to darken...

Darkness - and out of the darkness a noise like no other, horns and hooves and the shrill cry of birds and the roar of men and women. And over the dark fields, fringed with fire, high in the darkling sky flies a tumultuous host: thousands of Viking warriors and Valkyries packed togethe and riding plunging horses, armed with spears and swords, half-naked shield-maidens with bows and shields, sweeping across the heavens in a wild hunt amidst thick flocks of wheeling ravens. And in the midst of this vast ghostly army the huge figur Odin, the god of dead warriors, lord of Valhalla, riding eight-legged horse Sleipnir, carrying his spear, two rave perched on his shoulders, his cloak streaming out behind his single-eye surveying this great, ecstatic, thundering host of the risen dead.

Winter. The embers of the fire still glow in the centre o the floor. We are close again on the baby’s face...as he sleeps in the crook of Ragnar’s arm. Ragnar is awake, staring up into the darkness and the pla shadows across the rafters, a look of profound awe upon h face.

Now everything is in the fierce grip of the deepest winte Icy winds blast across the fjord, heaping the water into wild, foaming waves, and the mountains above are thick wi snow. Even at mid-day the sky is almost dark, like a perpetual twilight. But through this dark desolation a solitary FIGURE can be seen, a black smudge against the snow, wrapped in furs against the icy winds, struggling towards the hamlet.
Lagertha plays with her two CHILDREN. Her son BJORN is ab ten and daughter GYDA about eight years old. Ragnar appears, gestures to her.

Come. Ragnar leads Lagertha into the main room. RAGNAR (CONT’D) Here is the man I told you of, Lagertha. He indicates the figure standing beside the fire: a tall of uncertain age, his craggy face heavily lined, his hair beard both long and matted, as if his journey has been lo and arduous.

Welcome, stranger, to our house. The strange man bows a little. Lagertha pours a drink of sweet, strong mead and hands it to him. The stranger empt the cup.  LAGERTHA (CONT’D) Sit by the fire, warm yourself. The stranger nods again, and sits, Ragnar and Lagertha do likewise.
This man is a wanderer. He has been on a boat that travelled to the west. This is clearly a shock to Lagertha. She stares at the ma

Is it true? Once more the stranger nods, but does not reply. Lagertha suddenly realizes that he is glancing towards his cup, an she quickly re-fills it. And once more he empties it, then belches, and wipes his over his mouth.
We sailed north up the coast, to the rock formation which looks like a skull. And then, when we were out in the open sea, we turned due west. And I was frightened.
What happened to you? Where did you get to? Behind her, we see Bjorn and Gyda peeking into the room, listening.

After two days and nights we saw land. Someone said it was a land called England, for they had been there before. But I don’t know if it’s true. I was only told that in this land there was great treasure. We went ashore, found a big house there, and took some things from it. From his bundle of discarded furs he retrieves an object: small but very beautiful ivory crucifix.  WANDERER (CONT’D) In England, they worship a strange god called Jesus Christ. They say he died in a tree.
Like Odin. Only Odin came back to life. Lagertha examines the glittering prize.
Tell us how you crossed the open ocean - once you lost sight of land? How did you know you were sailing west, not north or south?
We had a board. It belonged to a Swede.
A board? What kind of board...?

A sun-shadow board. Here is one. Again he reaches into the thick pile of animal furs and t time produces a “solskuggerfol” board. It is a smallish wooden board with a pin or gnomon in the centre (which ca adjusted up or down) and with circles drawn around the pi WANDERER (CONT’D) To show you how it works, I need to float it in a tub of water. Ragnar goes off to fetch one. Once more the wanderer looks at his empty cup, and once m Lagertha re-fills it. And once more he empties the cup in one gulp. Outside the wind blasts against the house and makes the candles insid flutter and almost gutter. Ragnar returns with the tub of water and the wanderer pla the board in the water, where it floats. Then he takes a candle. WANDERER (CONT’D) This candle is the sun.  He holds the candle over the board. WANDERER (CONT’D) Each day the sun rises, and climbs in the sky until noon. (he arcs the candle across the board - the shadow shortens) See how the shadow shortens. At noon it will be at its shortest as the sun is at its zenith.
But this only tells me how far south I have travelled -

Now listen. The day before you sail, mark a circle around the pointer on the board at the place where the shadow is shortest at noon. The next day at sea, place the board in water again around noon and watch for the shadow. If it only touches the circle, your course remains true. If the shadow passes outside the circle, like this, you have drifted and must steer further south. If the shadow never reaches the circle you are to the south and must steer more north. Keep the noon shadow on the circle and your course will be true. Ragnar and Lagertha stare at the board and the shadow as moves across it.
Is it really true, wanderer, that you crossed the ocean using only this...this children’s toy?
Yes, I swear to you. I swear on my sacred ring. Of course, we also used ravens to show how far we might be from land, but the board took us across the open sea.
I cannot believe it.  Ragnar looks at her.

But if it’s true, Lagertha, just imagine! In just two days and nights we can reach the coast of England. We can find out for ourselves if what people have said is there really is there: rich lands, buildings made of stone, places filled with treasures. Don’t you want to go and find out? I do. A long beat. Lagertha looks at the board, then at the wanderer. Then she blows out the candle, plunging the board into darkness.
Why did you do that?
Because there is something I want to know. I want to know what happens if there is no sun? How can the board help you then? How can you find your way.
You use this. He holds something out in his hand, but they can’t see wh it is. Ragnar brings another candle closer - and it shine upon a piece of semi-transluscent rock (actually a form o calcite).
What’s that?
A sunstone.
What good is it? The wanderer smiles.
I‘1l show you. Come outside. Ragnar leads them outside.  10.
They look up at the sky - even now, around noon, it’s a leaden grey, with no sign of the sun.

Watch. He holds up the sunstone. A beat. (The calcite works by polarizing light). The sunstone glows faintly, and an equally faint beam see to bounce back from it and illuminate a spot in the sky, behind the thick clouds. WANDERER (CONT’D) You see? There is the sun. It seems like a miracle. Neither Ragnar nor Lagertha can speak as they bear witness to it.

Time has passed. Watched by her ten-year old daughter GYD Lagertha draws water from the well. Despite her reputatio a shield-maiden, Lagertha remains a slim, slight figure, long braided hair. It’s still cold enough for her breath to steam, but the i blasts of winter are over and the landscape breathes and greens. As she carries the bucket back towards the house we see various animals in timbered pens, for this is a working f And down by the water, a couple of small wooden boats. Two large and hairy hunting dogs shamble around the yard. Lagertha looks over at a neighboring property, where the HOUSEHOLDER is leaving, riding a small, wiry horse up the steep trail behind the houses. Glances back at her daughter.

Gyda, feed the goats.  11. INT. RAGNAR’S HOUSE - DAY Lagertha, carrying the bucket inside, finds Ragnar puttin thick woollen coat over the shoulders of his son, BJORN, twelve years old, and a handsome, strong-looking youth. Lagertha stops and looks at them.
What are you two doing?
I’m taking Bjorn to the Thing.
Not yet. He’s not old enough.
He’s twelve years old.
Take him next year. Next year is soon enough. Ragnar smiles at her.
He’1l need a silk ribbon.

BJORN “spies” on his mother as Lagertha washes her long blonde hair in the tub of water. The water seems to flow slow motion from the ends of her hair like mercury as she kneels over the tub. His eyes are full of love for her.
(quietly) Mother. Lagertha looks up, flicks back her hair so she can see hi and smiles tenderly.
Ragnar and Lagertha in bed together, cradled close after making. She stares into his eyes.  12.
Don’t sleep with too many women in Kattegat.
Are you crazy? I won’t sleep with any of them. I don’t want to. I can do without it for a few weeks.
Is that another way of saying you love me? She teases him.
I always dream of you. Last night I dreamt you were feeding me blood pudding.
What does that mean?
It means you were giving me your heart. And they close in, and kiss passionately.
I love you so much I could feed you the whole sky.

Father and son are ready to depart on their small, tough horses, both wearing heavy woollen coats, tight leather trousers, cloaks and leather boots. Lagertha and Gyda bring out some food for the journey, putting it into their saddle-bags. Bjorn kisses Gyda.
Goodbye, little sister.
Goodbye, big brother. Don’t get drunk.  13.

Wait. I have something for both of you. She takes out two thin strips of colored ribbon, and ties around Bjorn’s head and the other around her husband's. LAGERTHA (CONT’D) There. Now everyone will know you are free men on your way to the Thing. Ragnar kisses her.
Goodbye my shield-maiden.

Look after your son - and when you come back, just tell me the truth. I don’t care about anything else. And then she and her daughter watch Ragnar and Bjorn set up the rough trail towards the trees, accompanied by one the hunting dogs, Ragnar armed with a spear, a sword and knife and Bjorn with his hunting knife. Bjorn looks back once, and raises his arm in farewell, an then they are swallowed up into the trees.

They ride slowly on together through a landscape of fores scrub and rock. There is no-one else in sight, no farms o dwellings, for the rocky earth here is clearly unfit for agriculture or ploughing. Is even too barren for sheep. There are signs of spring everywhere, however, the trees brighter green, the gorse in flower.
What will happen at the Thing?
Earl Haraldson will deal, as usual, with some criminal offences that have happened since the last meeting. And then everyone will discuss the summer raids.
Where will you go?  14. There’s a long beat. Ragnar glances at his son, then away again, with a shrug.

It’s not up to me. Earl Haraldson decides. I wish it was not so...but that is the law. But Bjorn can see that the question has affected his fath mood. They splash through a stream. RAGNAR (CONT’D) All the ice has gone. Spring is here again, thanks to Frey.
They have camped in the open. A fire is burning and they cooked some small animal over it and eaten it. The dog gn at the bones.
There’s something I want to ask you.
Then ask me.
How did you meet mother? Ragnar’s smiles.
Hasn’t she ever told you?
Of course. But I want to know if your story is the same as hers. A beat.

Well, it occurred when a Swedish chieftan invaded our part of Norway. I went off to fight him and many of the local women dressed up in men’s clothing and joined our camp. Lagertha was amongst them. (MORE)
I was impressed by her courage and courted her from afar.
How far is that?

Hush. Listen. After a while I went to confess my love for her - but when I arrived I was set upon by a bear and an enormous hound who guarded her home. I killed the bear with my spear and managed to strangle the hound with my bare hands. (beat) And that’s the way I gained her hand in marriage. (glances at his son) What did she tell you? Bjorn smiles, then lies down, pulls the blanket over hims
Did she tell you the same story? A long beat.
Just about. And he closes his eyes, still smiling.

They ride into Kattegat, a sizeable town and a trading station, set on the bank of a river. It’s a busy place wi open carts and covered wagons, horses and boats bringing people and goods to the local market, as well as delegate the Thing, wearing ribbons around their foreheads. At the market place, TRADERS - several of them of Arabic appearance, and dressed in totally different costumes - a examining the pelts, furs, ropes and bear-skins for sale. The ARABS are also examining the handful of SLAVES for sa most of Slavic appearance, checking their teeth, hair and nails, as if they were horses. There is a lot of good-humored banter and loud haggling. All of this Bjorn has clearly seen before, and is not faz by.  16. But then a large group of YOUNG MEN, clearly drunk, come swaggering through the market place, shouting out insults the traders and laughing, grabbing at the pelts and furs, creating a disturbance. The traders reclaim their goods and drive them away, angr Ragnar watches the incident with a heavy heart.
Who are they?
Young men with nothing better to do. These days they regard the old ways, of trading and farming, as too tame. They think it’s stupid to acquire by sweat and toil what they can easily win by blood.
Blood?

In battle. (beat) It’s a real problem. There seem to be more and more of them every year. And it’s a great waste. Those young men are our future. Someone should harness their strength and their anger. They move on. Then a great bear of a man steps out before their horses, grabbing the bridles and laughing.
Ragnar Lothbrok! Ragnar and Bjorn dismount. Ragnar embraces him. BEAR MAN (CONT’D) Do my eyes deceive me? Is this your son? How he’s grown!
Bjorn, this is your uncle Rollo. We sail in the same boat.
Uncle. Rollo looks him up and down.  17.
So you’re here for the Thing? You’re a real man now. Let’s have a drink.
A long gloomy room, with a fire in the centre and benches arranged on either side. The men drink ale from horned cups. Rollo watches Bjorn s from his horn, and laughs.

You won’t get drunk like that. Bjorn smiles uneasily, then tips back the horn and drinks deeply. ROLLO (CONT’D) Are you ready for a woman? There are some good-looking women in Kattegat. And they’re free.
Of course he isn’t. He can’t even grow a beard. Rollo laughs again, empties his horn, and holds it out to refilled by a WOMAN with a jug. He stares at her wolfishl
So - where do you think he’1l send us this year?
Probably to the Eastlands again - the same as last year. The same as always.
Those bastards up there are as poor as we are. What do they have left to give us?
Only themselves. A beat. He glances round, lowers his voice.  18.
We should go west. I’ve heard such tales, Rollo. Great towns, cities and treasures; hordes of gold and silver. And a new god.

I’ve heard those stories too. But what does it mean? We can’t sail across an open ocean. A beat. Ragnar glances carefully at Bjorn, who has fallen asleep on his thigh. Lowers his voice again, despite the loud, drunken voices around him.
We can. I believe there’s a way. Rollo looks at him. Then Ragnar picks up his son.
Where are you going?
To sleep.
I don’t understand you, Ragnar Lothbrok, everyone else comes here to get drunk in the company of good friends and to fuck beautiful women . Ragnar smiles.

I’1l see you in the Great Hall. He carries his son away. INT. RAGNAR’S HOUSE - NIGHT Outside, a cold wind whips across the waters of the fjord Lagertha settles her daughter to sleep, telling her a sto
The giantess opened her rotting cavernous mouth and yawned. “Go away!” She said. “I want to sleep again. (MORE )

I’m not doing you any more favors.” She gave Freya a withering look. “My noble goddess,”she said, “you leap around at night like Heidrun cavorting with a herd of goats.” Gyda, warm beneath a bear skin, smiles sleepily. A beat.
Go on!

Freya slowly raised her arms - like this! (raises her own arms) “I will girdle you with flame so you cannot leave this place without catching fire.” Hyndla laughed. “You’ve gone running to Od, who always loved you; and many another has wormed his way under your apron.” She pauses, checks the girl again...whose eyes are now closed. She is nearly asleep. LAGERTHA (CONT’D) (more quietly) There was fire in Asgard, dancing in the air. A band of flame, a quivering halo, surrounded the giantess. Her limbs tightened; she pressed her arms against her side.” Flames about me,” she cried. “The earth is on fire, and I must pay the full price or forfeit my life.” She stops, listens for a moment to the sound of her daughter’s easy breathing. Then leans down, kisses her forehead, and pulls the bear skin up to her neck. Lagertha moves through to the other chamber. The fire (in centre of the room) is dying down. But its flickering fla illuminate the war shields hung from hooks on the wall. S stares at them - and then unhooks one, and holds it to herself...as if remembering all the times she used it, in heat of battle. Now she stands proud with it, in the empty room, with onl the crackling of the logs and the moaning of the wind.  20.

A large and impressive chamber with a lattice of high bea and some wall coverings. It’s crowded. On a raised dais a one end, sat on a carved chair, is EARL HARALDSON, late forties and still a formidable-looking warrior, dressed i wide trousers and fur-trimmed coat. The Earl is flanked b some of his HOUSECARLS - his private, elite bodyguard - b SLAVES and several (mostly male) members of his FAMILY. H striking WIFE wears a sleeveless dress which reaches to t ground, and over it a sleeveless cape which is thrown bac revealing the whiteness of her arms. She is adorned with necklaces and oval brooches. Filling the rest of the hall, and obliged to stand, are FREEMEN like Ragnar and Rollo. In the small space between them a rather pathetic FIGURE standing, shifting from one foot to the other, his eyes downcast. He’s almost a figure of fun and everyone is grinning at him.
Olaf Anwend...
Yes, sir.
You have pleaded guilty to the charge of stealing. Tomorrow you will run a gauntlet of stones and turf as punishment.
Yes, lord. Thank you, lord.

Don’t thank me. And let it be known that a fine is to be paid by anyone who fails to throw something. There’s laughter - as Olaf is led away. Bjorn tries his b to peer through the men blocking his view of events.

Bring in the next accused. Bjorn actually catches a glimpse of the YOUNG MAN brought into the hall in chains by the housecarls. The young man a pleasant expression, keeps his head high and does not a his eyes.  21.
Eric Trygvasson, you are accused of the murder of Sigvald Strut this January. How do you plead?
It wasn’t murder, lord. I killed him in self-defence. It was he who attacked me.
(shouting)
The WOMAN is part of the dead man’s family, standing in a group close to the defendant.

If it wasn’t murder, why did you not declare your crime to the first person you met afterwards, as the law obliges? In fact, you passed by several houses before you reported it. Trygvasson looks over at the woman and the dead man’s fam
I...I thought the relatives of the dead man might be living in them.
The law allows you to pass two houses in such circumstances - but never a third.
You felt guilty. You went to his house and murdered my brother in cold blood. Fresh uproar. Bjorn struggles to keep an eye-line on the accused. Ragnar notices, lifts him up.
It’s not true. We argued about some land. He pulled out a knife...
You’re lying! You wanted that land for yourself. You're a liar and a coward.  22.
Who says I’m a coward? I’m no coward. More people join in the shouting. The Earl bangs his fist the table.
Silence! All of you - show some respect. They fall silent. Earl Haraldson looks at Trygvasson.

As the normal procedures were not followed, this killing cannot be atoned for by compensating the victim’s family. The family shout their approval, raise their fists aggressively towards the defendant.

Murder is a dishonorable act among our people, Eric Trygvasson, committed in secret, unacknowledged and very likely to set in train a cycle of revenge killings, which would also involve your own family. He looks up at the assembly.

I ask all of you how you find the accused. If you think him guilty, raise your arms. Your decision must be unanimous. Quickly, everyone raises their hands. But the Earl hesita for someone has not. Ragnar realizes who it is and squeez Bjorn’s thigh. Bjorn raises his hand.
Eric Trygvasson, you have been found guilty of murder. How would you like to die? A beat. Trygvasson looks round the room in that same cool way, as if he was above it all.
By beheading, lord.  23.
Granted. Your execution will take place tomorrow. And afterwards we shall feast and discuss the summer raids.

To jeers and shouts, Olaf Anwend runs the gauntlet of sto and turf. He staggers down the line of people, women as w as men, throwing the missiles at him. Bjorn watches with Ragnar, at first enjoying the comic aspects of the scene - then wincing slightly as Olaf is struck by stone after stone, staggers, and starts to blee Ragnar offers the boy a stone. Bjorn looks uncertain.

You have to. A beat. Ragnar turns and throws the stone himself at Anwe hitting his leg. Anwend struggles on, everyone still enjo the comedic aspects. With a laugh Rollo throws a large ro at Anwend, which hits his head and makes him cry out with pain. Bjorn grabs a handful of turf and throws it, missing easi and deliberately. Bleeding heavily, but alive, Anwend crawls the last few y to the end of the line, where with renewed hilarity a buc of cold water is poured over his bleeding head, and he emerges - grinning like a madman. Then Earl Haraldson and his entourage appear, the houseca bringing Eric Trygvasson to his execution. Trygvasson’s hands, unlike at the trial, are now unbound, and he walks resolutely up to the wooden block on which he will be decapitated. He smiles at the crowds gathered around him, and acknowle the dead man’s family.
Why is he smiling, father?
He wants to die well, of course, without fear. To atone for his sins.
Bjorn looks puzzled.

Cattle die, kinsfolk die, we ourselves must die. But one thing I know will never die - a dead man’s reputation. Remember that, young Bjorn. Trygvasson kneels on the grass and puts his head on the stone. A HOUSECARL with an axe approaches, first lays the blade of the axe flat on his head, then presents the blad for him to kiss. Trygvasson kisses the blade eagerly, and almost tenderly. Bjorn turns his head away.

You must watch - for his sake. This is his only hope of reaching Valhalla. Bjorn forces himself to watch. The axe falls, striking off Trygvasson’s head, which roll away into the grass. Earl Haraldson picks up the head and contemptuously tosse to the dead man’s family.
Here. Feed it to your pigs. I curse him. May he never enter Valhalla. Ragnar looks shocked. He’s not the only one.
Why did he do that?
I don’t know. He should not have done. Not according to our law. He must have wanted that land himself. And he exchanges a meaningful glance with Rollo.

The oars of a small boat slice cleanly into the waters of fyord. Bjorn stares down silently into the water, but the reflections on its surface make it seem like the mountain are in the water.  25. Ragnar rows, keeping close to the shore, beneath the lee the overhanging cliffs and slopes of scree which fall she to the fyord. Bjorn drops a smooth round pebble into the water and watc it drop and drop, deeper and deeper into the clear depths Bjorn watches his father row.
Now where are we going, father?
To visit a friend.
A friend? What’s his name?
His name is Floki. Bjorn stares at the high, snow-capped hills, the great, almost overwhelming beauty of it.
Like Loki, the god?
Yes, like Loki. Only... different.
How is he different?
Well... (thinks) He’s not a god. Bjorn laughs.
Why didn’t he come to the Thing? A long beat. Oars slice through the deep still waters. On could well imagine that the gods were here, among these unnaturally beautiful, silent places.
Because he’s...because he’s shy.

They’ve pulled the boat onto a narrow beach in a hidden b There’s no sign of habitation. They walk up a steep path through the trees. When a FIGURE leaps out at them, wearing a fierce mask, a with a hideous screech. Bjorn is shocked...but still calm enough to draw out his hunting knife. Ragnar laughs.

It’s all right. Put your knife away. (beat) Floki, meet my son. Bjorn...this is my dear friend Floki. FLOKI rips off his mask, and grins. He has a strange, mischievous, almost ageless face, ugly but animated, with bright, piercing eyes.
Hello. How are you?
Well, thank you...sir. Floki stares at his face.
Let me see. You have your father’s eyes - unfortunately.
Why unfortunately?
It means he will be like you. And therefore he will want to do better than you. And you will hate him for it.
He’s only twelve years old.  27.
How can you tell that by just looking at my face?
It’s the same with trees.
With trees?
Yes. I can tell which trees will make the best planks just by looking at them. I can look inside the tree.
Floki is a boat-builder. Bjorn stares around at the deeply-forested hill they are

So - you could tell which of these trees would make the best planks for a ship? Floki grins...then abruptly walks off the path, and into trees. They follow him. For their POV - and from ours - all the trees look the sa virtually identical. But Floki stares at them with a strange, bewitching intensity....touching the trunks of some of them, laying cheek against the bark, staring up at the uppermost branc Whatever amusement Bjorn might derive from seeing a man staring at trees is quickly confounded by the aura of spiritual intensity which surrounds Floki. He’s no ordina mortal. It’s not possible to laugh at the way he examines bark of tress, or caresses them, or simply just looks at them. Floki is different. Strange but compelling. Authentic.

(suddenly) This is one. He indicates a tree - to the others, just like the rest o the trees...and yet. Floki strokes the trunk.  28. FLOKI (CONT’D) Inside this tree are two almost perfect planks. They will bend, then curve, like a woman’s body, from the thigh to the back. When I split the tree I will find them. He marks the tree with a couple of blows from his axe. Bjorn laughs.
You can see that?
Do you think I’m joking? I joke about many things, son of Ragnar, but never about ship-building. Our boats are our souls. Bjorn looks abashed - embarrassed.
So - how is our boat? Floki looks back at him. And grins.
Ah...

A secret, turf-covered shed close by the edge of the wate Gloomy - but slightly “religious” in the way the space is by tallow candles. Watched by Ragnar and Bjorn, Floki uncovers the skeleton a new boat. It’s still in a rudimentary shape, its spars naked. Even so, Ragnar is immediately entranced.
What do you think, Ragnar Lothrok?
It’s bigger! The hull’s deeper.  29.

Yes, but it will be lighter and faster than before, and carry a much bigger sail. The construction is different. It’s built with a strong central plank. The two strakes above it are nailed directly onto the knees of the frames. But the ones below - look! - are cleated and lashed onto the frames, not nailed, so they can move in relation to each other. This means the boat will not butt against the waves like a goat, but move over them like a ripple. Ragnar continues to study the boat. Meanwhile, Bjorn studies Floki’s tools with all the fascination they exert upon a young boy’s mind. Planes, s shaped bores, small axes and rivets. And then, almost wit shock, he sees the small, strange figure hunched in the shadows, wearing a conical hat and grinning. It’s a woode statue of the god Loki and the grin is not pleasant, but wicked and somehow disturbing. Bjorn moves quickly away.
Why have you cut the oarports into the sheerstrake?
It makes it easier to row, and the ports can be closed when the boat is at sea.
You think this boat could handle long sea voyages?
That’s why I built it.
And it will be strong enough? Floki shrugs.
We won’t know that until we try. Ragnar looks at him.  30.
When will it be ready?
Ah, as to that...
What?
We’re out of money. We have to pay for the sail...and then the anchor. You know what those blacksmiths are like! Such greedy bastards. A beat. Ragnar reluctantly brings out a leather pouch.
This is almost all I have left from last summer’s raids. Floki takes the pouch, with a grin.
Don’t worry, Ragnar Lothbrok. We’1l soon be as rich as dwarves! And he laughs.

Great trestles have been set up and the freemen sit aroun them, drinking and ready to feast. Music is playing. Earl Haraldson, with his wife and family members, sits at high table. There is much laughter in the hall. Then a horn is sounde for silence.

Before we feast, we have an important ceremony to perform. Two young men have joined us for the first time and must receive their arm-rings. Olaf the son of Ingolf and Bjorn son of Ragnar Lothbrok. Both of you come up here. Bjorn and the other YOUNG MAN approach the high table. Th Earl walks round to the front of the dais...and draws his sword.  31.
